Description: The bust-length personification of Charity appears as a golden figure against a blue enamel background with green and white enamel borders. The engraved outlines of the face, hands and drapery are highlighted with red enamel as is the lettering. This technique and combination of colors is characteristic of enamels made in the vicinity of Cologne, Germany, in the second half of the twelfth century. Charity and its mate, Justice (Walters 44.99), plausibly were part of a series illustrating virtues adorning a book cover, reliquary shrine or portable altar.

Exhibitions.Textblock: Arts of the Middle Ages. Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Boston. 1940.

Inscriptions:
In red enamel on gold gilded scroll above Charity's head: CARITAS; [Translation] Charity.

Stamped with makers mark on reverse.
Medium: champlevé enamel on copper with gilding

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Centre Street: Third Floor: Romanesque and Gothic Art

Provenance: A. Tollin, Paris, by purchase; Sale, Hotel Drouot, Paris, May 20, 1897, no. ???; Jacques Seligmann, Paris, by purchase; Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1922, by purchase; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Charity
